definition:
Let $X$ be a Banach space and $T:X\to X$ a continuous linear
isomorphism. We say that $T$ is an *hyperbolic isomorphism* if its
spectrum is disjoint with the unit circle, i.e.
$\sigma(T)\cap \{z\in {\mathbb{C}}:|z|=1\}=\emptyset$.

If this is the case, by the spectral theorem there is a splitting of $X$
into two invariant subspaces, $X=E^s\oplus E^u$ (and therefore, a
corresponding splitting of $T$ into two operators $T^s:E^s\to E^s$ and
$T_u:E^u\to E^u$, i.e. $T=T_s\oplus
T_u$), such that $\sigma(T_s) = \sigma(T)\cap \{z:|z|<1\}$ and
$\sigma(T_u)=\sigma(T)\cap\{z:|z|>1\}$. Also, for any $\lambda$ greater
than the spectral radius of both $T_s$ and $T_u^{-1}$ there exists an
equivalent (box-type) norm $\|\cdot\|_1$ such that
$$\|T_s\|_1 < \lambda \textnormal{ and } \|T_u^{-1}\|_1 < \lambda$$ and
$$\|x\|_1 = \max\{\|x_u\|_1,\|x_s\|_1\}.$$ In particular, $\lambda$ can
be chosen smaller than $1$, so that $T_s$ and $T_u^{-1}$ are
contractions.
